BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: In the late morning danger level 4 (high) will be reached in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As the snowfall becomes more intense the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase in the late morning.
The fresh snow and the wind slabs that are forming in particular above approximately 2400 m can be released easily in all aspects.
In the regions exposed to heavier precipitation avalanches are possible as the day progresses, even very large ones.
Over a wide area rain to intermediate altitudes. Gradual increase in danger of moist and wet avalanches as the snowfall level rises.
Ski touring and other off-piste activities, including snowshoe hiking, call for extensive experience and great restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 40 to 70 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Friday above approximately 2200 m. The southerly wind will transport the new snow.
In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with each other and the old snowpack.
The rain gave rise to moistening of the snowpack in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.
In particular at intermediate and high altitudes a lot of snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: In the late morning danger level 4 (high) will be reached in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation. Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. The danger of moist and wet avalanches will increase during the day.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As the snowfall becomes more intense the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase in the late morning. The wind will be moderate to strong.
The fresh snow and the wind slabs that are forming in particular above approximately 2300 m can be released easily in all aspects.
In the regions exposed to heavier precipitation avalanches are possible as the day progresses, even very large ones.
Gradual increase in danger of moist and wet avalanches as a consequence of warming.
Ski touring and snowshoe hiking call for extensive experience and great restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 30 to 60 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until Sunday above approximately 2200 m. The southerly wind will transport the new snow.
In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with each other and the old snowpack. The old snowpack is well consolidated and its surface consists of loosely bonded snow lying on a strong melt-freeze crust.
The high temperatures gave rise to moistening of the snowpack in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.
In particular at intermediate and high altitudes there is still a very large amount of snow. Below approximately 2000 m hardly any snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: In the late morning danger level 4 (high) will be reached in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation. Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. The danger of moist and wet avalanches will increase during the day.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As the snowfall becomes more intense the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase in the late morning. The wind will be moderate to strong.
The fresh snow and the wind slabs that are forming in particular above approximately 2300 m can be released easily in all aspects.
In the regions exposed to heavier precipitation avalanches are possible as the day progresses, even very large ones.
Gradual increase in danger of moist and wet avalanches as a consequence of warming.
Ski touring and snowshoe hiking call for extensive experience and great restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 30 to 60 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until Sunday above approximately 2200 m. The southerly wind will transport the new snow.
In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with each other and the old snowpack. The old snowpack is well consolidated and its surface consists of loosely bonded snow lying on a strong melt-freeze crust.
The high temperatures gave rise to moistening of the snowpack in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.
In particular at intermediate and high altitudes there is still a very large amount of snow. Below approximately 2000 m hardly any snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. The danger of moist and wet avalanches will increase during the day.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Snowfall at intermediate altitudes. The wind will be moderate to strong. In the late morning the wind slabs will increase in size additionally. These are to be assessed with care and prudence, especially adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas. These can sometimes be released, even by a single winter sport participant, in particular on very steep slopes above approximately 2300 m.
As the precipitation becomes more intense dry and moist avalanches are possible from the late morning, but they can be large in isolated cases, especially on very steep slopes, and at the base of rock walls in high Alpine regions.
Along the border between Valais and Italy and at higher altitudes the danger of dry avalanches is higher.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 15 to 50 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until Sunday above approximately 2200 m. The southerly wind will transport the new snow.
In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with each other and the old snowpack. The old snowpack is well consolidated and its surface consists of loosely bonded snow lying on a strong melt-freeze crust.
The high temperatures gave rise to moistening of the snowpack in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.
In particular at intermediate and high altitudes there is still a very large amount of snow. Below approximately 2000 m hardly any snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As the day progresses as a consequence of warming there will be an increase in the danger of moist and wet avalanches.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. The danger of moist and wet avalanches will increase during the day.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Snowfall at intermediate altitudes. The wind will be moderate to strong. In the late morning the wind slabs will increase in size additionally. These are to be assessed with care and prudence, especially adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas. These can sometimes be released, even by a single winter sport participant, in particular on very steep slopes above approximately 2300 m.
As the precipitation becomes more intense dry and moist avalanches are possible from the late morning, but they can be large in isolated cases, especially on very steep slopes, and at the base of rock walls in high Alpine regions.
Along the border between Valais and Italy and at higher altitudes the danger of dry avalanches is higher.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 15 to 50 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until Sunday above approximately 2200 m. The southerly wind will transport the new snow.
In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with each other and the old snowpack. The old snowpack is well consolidated and its surface consists of loosely bonded snow lying on a strong melt-freeze crust.
The high temperatures gave rise to moistening of the snowpack in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.
In particular at intermediate and high altitudes there is still a very large amount of snow. Below approximately 2000 m hardly any snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As the day progresses as a consequence of warming there will be an increase in the danger of moist and wet avalanches.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights:
As a consequence of warming, the likelihood of wet loose snow avalanches being released will increase in all aspects.
The wind slabs of the last few days must be evaluated with care and prudence.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. In particular on sunny slopes wet loose snow avalanches are possible. Individual gliding avalanches can also occur. In all aspects large and, in isolated cases, very large avalanches are possible.
Avalanches can be released by a single winter sport participant.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
As a consequence of new snow and wind, wind slabs formed. They must be evaluated with care and prudence. Wind slabs are lying on a hard crust. Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be severely restricted over a wide area. The weather conditions will give rise to increasing moistening of the snowpack.
Weak layers exist in the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Over a wide area continuous warming.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wet snow represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Above approximately 2200 m snow will fall over a wide area. The wind will be moderate.
In particular on wind-loaded slopes dry avalanches can be triggered in the new snow and wind slab layers and reach large size in some cases. In the regions exposed to heavier precipitation this applies in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls as well as.
Over a wide area rain to intermediate altitudes: Medium-sized to large moist and wet avalanches are to be expected.
Ski touring and other off-piste activities, including snowshoe hiking, call for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 30 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Friday above approximately 2200 m. The southerly wind will transport the new snow.
In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with each other and the old snowpack. This applies especially in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.
In particular at intermediate and high altitudes a lot of snow is lying.
The rain gave rise to moistening of the snowpack in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Increase in danger of wet and gliding avalanches from early morning. Individual avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found on very steep shady slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The danger of wet avalanches will already increase in the early morning.
Especially on rocky sunny slopes small to medium-sized wet loose snow avalanches are to be expected. As the day progresses also on shady slopes there will be an increase in the danger of wet avalanches.
In addition individual small and medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible. This applies on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.

Weak layers in the upper part of the snowpack can still be released in isolated cases by winter sport participants on very steep shady slopes. Especially shady slopes are unfavourable, in particular above approximately 2400 m. Mostly avalanches are medium-sized. The avalanche prone locations are difficult to recognise.
In addition the fresh wind slabs in high Alpine regions are prone to triggering in some cases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The surface of the snowpack will cool hardly at all during the overcast night and will soften quickly, especially on sunny slopes below approximately 2800 m. The high temperatures as the day progresses will give rise to increasing softening of the snowpack also on shady slopes at elevated altitudes.

Isolated avalanche prone weak layers exist in the top section of the snowpack especially on shady slopes.
As a consequence of a sometimes strong southwesterly wind, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs will form in the vicinity of peaks, especially in high Alpine regions. The weather effects will bring about a rapid stabilisation of the snow drift accumulations.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The danger of dry avalanches will decrease gradually. The danger of wet avalanches will persist.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Increase in danger of wet and gliding avalanches from early morning. Individual avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found on very steep shady slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The danger of wet avalanches will already increase in the early morning.
Especially on rocky sunny slopes small to medium-sized wet loose snow avalanches are to be expected. As the day progresses also on shady slopes there will be an increase in the danger of wet avalanches.
In addition individual small and medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible. This applies on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.

Weak layers in the upper part of the snowpack can still be released in isolated cases by winter sport participants on very steep shady slopes. Especially shady slopes are unfavourable, in particular above approximately 2400 m. Mostly avalanches are medium-sized. The avalanche prone locations are difficult to recognise.
In addition the fresh wind slabs in high Alpine regions are prone to triggering in some cases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The surface of the snowpack will cool hardly at all during the overcast night and will soften quickly, especially on sunny slopes below approximately 2800 m. The high temperatures as the day progresses will give rise to increasing softening of the snowpack also on shady slopes at elevated altitudes.

Isolated avalanche prone weak layers exist in the top section of the snowpack especially on shady slopes.
As a consequence of a sometimes strong southwesterly wind, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs will form in the vicinity of peaks, especially in high Alpine regions. The weather effects will bring about a rapid stabilisation of the snow drift accumulations.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The danger of dry avalanches will decrease gradually. The danger of wet avalanches will persist.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow and wind slabs are lying on a crust in all aspects above approximately 2000 m. Adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent and larger. Wind slabs can in some places be released by a single winter sport participant and reach medium size. Small and medium-sized natural avalanches are possible in particular on very steep sunny slopes. Backcountry touring calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The covering of new snow is soft. Over a wide area new snow is lying on an icy crust. Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be good over a wide area. As a consequence of rising temperatures and solar radiation a crust will form on the surface during the next few days.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The sometimes deep wind slabs of the last few days can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases in particular on wind-protected shady slopes above approximately 2500 m.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Some fresh snow and the sometimes deep wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In particular adjacent to ridgelines as well as at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs formed.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wet snow represents the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Individual moist and wet avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The solar radiation will give rise from early morning to increasing and thorough wetting of the snowpack. The meteorological conditions will facilitate a weakening of the snowpack in particular in gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in terrain.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The danger of wet avalanches will already increase in the early morning.
Especially on rocky east, south and west facing slopes mostly small wet avalanches are to be expected. As the day progresses also on shady slopes there will be only a slight increase in the danger of wet avalanches.
In addition very occasional mostly small gliding avalanches are possible. This applies on steep grassy slopes. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The surface of the snowpack cooled hardly at all during the overcast night and will soften quickly, especially on sunny slopes below approximately 2800 m. The high temperatures as the day progresses will give rise to increasing softening of the snowpack also on shady slopes at elevated altitudes.

At low and intermediate altitudes hardly any snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The danger of wet avalanches will persist.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Increase in danger of wet and gliding avalanches from early morning.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The danger of wet avalanches will already increase in the early morning.
Especially on rocky east, south and west facing slopes mostly small wet avalanches are to be expected. As the day progresses also on shady slopes there will be an appreciable increase in the danger of wet avalanches.
In addition very occasional mostly small gliding avalanches are possible. This applies on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.

Weak layers in the upper part of the snowpack can still be released in very isolated cases by winter sport participants. Especially shady slopes are unfavourable. Mostly avalanches are rather small. The avalanche prone locations are difficult to recognise.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The surface of the snowpack cooled hardly at all during the overcast night and will soften quickly, especially on sunny slopes below approximately 2800 m. The high temperatures as the day progresses will give rise to increasing softening of the snowpack also on shady slopes at elevated altitudes.

Isolated avalanche prone weak layers exist in the top section of the snowpack especially on shady slopes. This applies at high altitude.

At low and intermediate altitudes hardly any snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The danger of dry avalanches will decrease quickly. The danger of wet avalanches will persist.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As a consequence of sharply falling temperatures the snowpack will consolidate during the next few days. Some fresh snow and the mostly small wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in particular on north to northeast to northwest facing aspects.
